DOC.HEAD: Leftists Bomb Temple, Threaten Mormons and U.S. Agents
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Pro-Cuban rebels dynamited a Mormon temple in an interior city and left leaflets threatening church workers and U.S. drug agents, a radio report said Friday. It said the threat was in response to the U.S. invasion of Panama. Police said the rebels also bombed a bank in suburban Lima. In neighboring Chile, suspected members of another radical leftist group doused a Mormon chapel in Santiago with gasoline and set it on fire. All three attacks caused damage but no casualties. Several temples of the Utah-based Mormon church and U.S. cultural centers have been attacked in both countries in recent days. Radio Programas broadcast its report from the jungle city of Tarapoto, 435 miles north of Lima, saying rebels of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement bombed the Mormon temple there Thursday night. The report said the rebels left behind leaflets telling Mormon church workers and U.S. drug agents to leave the department of San Martin within 10 days. Authorities in Tarapoto could not be reached Friday to confirm the story, and a U.S. Embassy spokesman in Lima said he had no information. The U.S.-built anti-drug base at Santa Lucia is in San Martin department. Twenty to 40 Americans, including agents, contract helicopter pilots and mechanics, are stationed there to help Peruvian police in raids against clandestine airstrips and drug laboratories used in the cocaine trade. Tupac Amaru rebels dynamited three Mormon temples and a Peruvian-American cultural center Tuesday in the northern coastal city of Chiclayo and another center Friday in Arequipa in the southern highlands. The pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru launched its armed insurgency against Peru's elected government in 1984. The group takes its name from a 18th century mestizo revolutionary who fought Spanish colonial rule in the Andean highlands. In the bank bombing, police said Tupac Amaru rebels detonated explosives at the Bandesco bank branch in residential San Isidro. In Friday's attack in Santiago, police said the fire was quickly extinguished at the small chapel in Villa Frei, a working-class neighborhood. The Lautaro Commando, a radical leftist organization, claimed responsibility for the attack, police said. It was the fifth attack on Mormon chapels since Sunday in Santiago and provincial cities. In the other attacks, four chapels were damaged by bombs. No one claimed responsibility for those blasts. In one case, the attackers wrote slogans on chapel walls condemning the Panamanian invasion. Late Thursday, a bomb exploded at the bathroom of the U.S. cultural center in downtown Santiago, causing damage but no victims, police said. The Lautaro group took responsibility for dozens of attacks on Mormon chapels in the last few years, saying the church is ``a tool of Yankee imperialism.'' The group takes its name from an Indian chief who fought the Spanish conquerors in the 16th century.
